title: Can I have a court force 401k provider (Vanguard) to cash out?
question: Getting way to far behind in all debts. I know there’s a tax penalty for early withdrawal. I’m still employed with my company and do not plan to leave. How can I get a full withdrawal? Can the court force withdrawal to prevent bankruptcy and foreclosure??
answers: See a bankruptcy attorney. EVEN IF your plan could be forced by YOU to give money out your creditors probably cannot. So deal with your shortfall with the BK attorney and change your spending habits thereafter.

More information is needed to give you useful advice. 1. Which court? Family court? Bankruptcy court? Civil Superior Court? 2. If you are getting behind on bills, you should consider filing BK because all retirement savings are exempt. In other words, you can file BK, discharge your unsecured debts, and keep your retirement money held in the 401k accounts. 3. If you are behind on house payments, you can file Chap 13 BK, pay off your past due amounts over as much as 60 months, keep your house, keep your retirement, keep other property too, like car, furniture, jewelry, etc.

Best advice? Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer". Set up 2-3 consultations. Many Avvo BK lawyers offer a free consultation to answer your many questions. BK is not a DIY project or just clicking the right boxes on forms. Good luck and God bless.

In most circumstances retirement benefits such as 401(k)s are fully exempt from collection, so a creditor cannot go after the funds. I know of no bankruptcy attorneys that would recommend using fully exempt assets to pay off dischargeable debts, so my question to you is: are the debts you are concerned with likely to be found to be non-dischargeable? Without going into each and every one, it is highly unlikely.

What you are considering is cashing out what you have saved for your survival when you are 70+ years old, to pay off debt which could be discharged or paid off in other ways (such as a debt consolidation, credit counseling or chapter 13 plan), and incurring taxes which you will have to pay next year.

Please reconsider. If your debts are that onerous, sit down with a bankruptcy attorney or other financial advisor to discuss other options. And as stated by Attorney Benda, it is unlikely that you can cash out your 401(k) for full cash value, and likely that you will have to pay back what you took out.

You can generally borrow, if the plan allows it, up to $50% of your vested amount and no more than $50,000. You have to repay it over a five-year period, which payments are withheld from your paycheck. You cannot liquidate your 401(k) nor can anyone force you to do so. Check with your company.
